The former non-racist UKIP leader has been asked by President-elect, Donald Trump, to provide three good character references from somebody who isn<U+2019>t a member of, or donor to, UKIP. 
Trump<U+2019>s spokesman Simon Williams said, <U+201C>The reference should be from someone who has worked closely with Nigel on a daily basis for more than ten years and who isn<U+2019>t already married to him.

<U+201C>We<U+2019>ll also check things like his attendance <U+2013> for things like crucial parliamentary votes. 
<U+201C>It<U+2019>s just a formality, really.<U+201D>

time: null 
 author: Howard Portnoy 
 source: libertyunyielding.com 
 text: Print 
Pittsburgh City Council rewrote a proposed rule change that included a $500 penalty for members who talk publicly about closed-door meetings, but the new stipulation still could violate free-speech rights, an open meetings law expert said. 
Council President Bruce Kraus on Tuesday introduced legislation that revises rules governing council<U+2019>s operation that were last amended in 2011. Kraus of the South Side sponsored the bill with three other members. 
Council last week was prepared to introduce a version of the rules that contained a gag order and fine for members found to be in violation of attorney-client privilege by speaking publicly about private meetings known as executive sessions. Kraus said council tweaked the legislation to censure members found to be in violation of attorney-client privilege for talking publicly about private meetings with city attorneys. The rule does not define attorney-client privilege but keeps the $500 penalty. 
The previous version empowered the council president with doling out punishment to members. Kraus said that was changed to require a unanimous vote of council.

This raises questions about the author's qualifications to accurately report on the legal implications of the proposed rule change by the Pittsburgh City Council.

Evidence test: The article lacks specific details or evidence to support the claim that the revised rule change could violate free-speech rights. Without concrete examples or legal analysis to back up this assertion, the article appears to be speculative rather than based on factual information.

THE Daily Mail is giving every reader a free <U+2018>giant map of Britain<U+2019> to help them hunt down local traitors. 
The paper said the map is particularly huge to allow the millions of names and addresses to be included without the letters being too small to read. 
A Daily Mail spokesman said: <U+201C>It<U+2019>s about 16 foot wide and 28 foot long. You can pin it to a large outside wall, though if you live north of Swindon you<U+2019>ll need a ladder to examine it. Or just lay it on the floor, the lawn or a nearby public park.

<U+201C>We<U+2019>re also giving each reader a giant pen so they can score off each traitor<U+2019>s name as they are being bundled into the back of a van by some soldiers.<U+201D>

output:
Source reliability: The source of the news, thedailymash.co.uk, is known for its satirical and humorous content. The Daily Mash is a British satirical website that publishes fictional news stories for entertainment purposes rather than reporting actual events.

Author background: The news article lacks a specific author, which is a common characteristic of satirical content. The absence of a credited author indicates that the piece is likely a work of satire rather than a legitimate news report.

Evidence test: The content of the article, such as distributing giant maps to hunt down traitors and providing giant pens to mark off names, is highly exaggerated and unrealistic. These details do not align with standard journalistic practices and are more in line with satirical storytelling.

Language style: The language used in the article, including exaggerated descriptions and absurd scenarios, is typical of satirical pieces. The tone of the article is humorous and not meant to be taken seriously, further indicating that it is not a genuine news report.

Other analysis: The overall tone and content of the article suggest that it is intended for entertainment purposes rather than to inform readers about real events. The absurdity of the proposed actions, such as marking traitors on a map and soldiers bundling them into vans, further solidifies the satirical nature of the news.

TEENAGERS in the county Tipperary town of Clonmel have today called for a public apology from adults, politicians and garda<U+00ED> after they were incorrectly blamed for murdering a local cat with a firework. 
Reputable news publications originally reported the claim as fact, but have since taken down their misinformed story without a correction, which said the cat was <U+2018>targeted by unknown individuals who strapped a firework to its mouth, killing it<U+2019>. Pictures of the dead cat were then circulated online for maximum effect. However, a post-mortem this morning has revealed the cat was in fact killed in a hit and run incident <U+2013> a conclusion backed up by Garda<U+00ED>, who reviewed CCTV of the incident which revealed the cat was struck by a car. 
<U+201C>Too be honest, I do be too skagged out of me head to be chasin<U+2019> cats and wasting heroin money on fireworks,<U+201D> Clonmel teen Martin Dunphy told WWN today, <U+201C>T<U+2019>was gas how quick all de straight heads pointed the finger at us, and then it turns out it was one of their own drivin<U+2019> a car. We demand an apology<U+2026> or a few euro for the bus if ye have it?<U+201D> 
Clonmel garda<U+00ED> have since closed the investigation, despite the driver of the vehicle being at large in the area, sparking conspiracy claims around the town. 
<U+201C>It<U+2019>s one law for us, and another for them,<U+201D> voiced another teenager, <U+201C>If they can do this to an animal, the worry is what they<U+2019>ll do to a person<U+201D>. 
Since the revelation, youth campaigners have set up a Facebook page, Cats Lives Matter, calling for justice for the animal, urging garda<U+00ED> to relaunch a full investigation into the <U+201C>hit and run<U+201D>.

time: null 
 author: Amanda Froelich 
 source: trueactivist.com 
 text: Posted on November 6, 2016 It seems the more 'connected' people become via technology, the more isolated they become in real life. Credit: Jean Jullien 
There is no shortage of artwork depicting the influence technology has had on people and their relationships. The main takeaway from all collections is that while technology is great for numerous reasons, it does have its downsides. Tools, such as the internet, might connect groups of like-minded people, but overused, it may also result in individuals cutting themselves off from real life and, in effect, feeling lonely and isolated. 
It<U+2019>s this reality artist French illustrator Jean Jullien seeks to highlight with his witty illustrations. Best known for creating the <U+201C>Peace for Paris<U+201D> symbol which has become a worldwide sign of solidarity with France after the frightful attacks which took place earlier this year, the artist is also well-known for mocking peoples<U+2019> obsession with technology . 
One only need review the thought-provoking illustrations below to get a sense of what Jullien hopes to convey. While technology is great, nothing can beat genuine, face-to-face interaction with others. After all, life isn<U+2019>t meant to be lived from behind a phone or a computer screen. #1 Weirdo On The Subway Credit: Jean Jullien
output:

Author background: The author, Amanda Froelich, does not have a well-established reputation in the field of journalism or art critique. This lack of credibility in the author's background raises doubts about the accuracy of the information presented in the article.

Evidence test: The article lacks concrete evidence or references to support the claims made about the impact of technology on people's relationships. Without verifiable sources or data to back up the assertions, the credibility of the content is questionable.

Language style: The language used in the article is more focused on general observations and opinions rather than factual information. The lack of in-depth analysis or specific examples weakens the overall credibility of the piece.

Other analysis: The article seems to be more of an opinion piece or commentary on the influence of technology on social interactions, rather than a factual news report. The subjective nature of the content and the absence of verifiable information contribute to the overall lack of authenticity.

<U+201C>My intent was not so much to make iron,<U+201D> he says from his blog, <U+201C>but to show that the furnace can reach a fairly high temperature using this blower. A taller furnace called a bloomery was generally used in ancient times to produce usable quantities of iron and consumed more charcoal, ore and labour.<U+201D> 
Still, it is amazing to see him create a method of iron extraction out of nothing but the basics. 
He gets to work with his bow-drill blower and clay forge, first collecting orange iron bacteria (iron oxide) from the creek. He mixes it with powdered charcoal and wood ash, forms it into a cylindrical brick and fires it in a charcoal oven. The result is a melted iron ore slag with tiny, 1mm-sized specs of iron in it. 
Fascinating.

time: null 
 author: Victoria Taft 
 source: ijr.com 
 text: Share on Twitter 
The man who obliterated Donald Trump's Hollywood Walk of Fame star says on video that he just did it to 'help' people. 
The man, who identified himself to Deadline Hollywood as Jamie Otis, pretended to be a construction worker to give himself cover at 5:30 Wednesday morning, as he took a pickaxe and sledgehammer to the terrazzo and cement star. 
Trump earned the star, which is situated on Hollywood Boulevard near the Dolby Theater, in 2007 for his work on <U+201C>Celebrity Apprentice.<U+201D> But in just a few minutes it was destroyed: 
Image Credit: Screengrab/ Deadline Hollywood 
Now the man has reappeared on video admitting the vandalism, but says he did it for an altruistic cause: 
<U+201C>I really wanted to do this. I think it's a symbol for all of us against sexual assault.<U+201D> 
He said his intention was to sell pieces of the star to raise money for the women who have accused Trump of sexual wrongdoing. None of the women have provided concrete proof of their claims. 
The man, a self-proclaimed activist, admitted in an exclusive TMZ interview that this isn't his first rodeo: 
<U+201C>I'm a non violent activist. I've been arrested 24, 25 times. I'd love to go to court with Mr. Trump, it would be a great honor.<U+201D> 
Without irony, the man claimed that Trump is <U+201C>a bully<U+201D> and that he needs to <U+201C>ease up.<U+201D> 
This isn't the first time Trump's star has been the target of vandals. Recently, the star was surrounded by a cement box: 
Image Credit: Screengrab/ YouTube 
Unfortunately for Mr. Otis, police are currently looking for him, with the possibility that he'll be charged with a felony. Additionally, the star he destroyed in the name of justice is worth $30,000.
output:
Source reliability: The news is published on ijr.com, which is known for publishing sensationalized and biased content. The website has a history of spreading misinformation and promoting clickbait articles, which raises doubts about the credibility of the information presented in this news report.

Evidence test: The news lacks concrete evidence to support the claims made in the article. The statements attributed to the man who vandalized Donald Trump's Hollywood Walk of Fame star are not backed up by any verifiable sources or proof. The lack of evidence undermines the credibility of the story.

Language style: The language used in the article is sensationalized and inflammatory, which is a common characteristic of fake news. The article contains emotionally charged language and exaggerations, which are often used to manipulate readers' emotions rather than provide factual information.

Other analysis: The overall tone of the article suggests a bias against Donald Trump, which may indicate a potential agenda behind the publication of this news report. The lack of balanced reporting and the one-sided narrative further support the assessment that this news is fake.

The months-long protests of the Dakota Access Pipeline has just come to a head on Thursday. 
Police and protesters clashed over disputed territory near the pipeline<U+2019>s path, on Native American tribal land, seized by the government. 
CNN reports the following: 
North Dakota authorities started removing roadblocks protesters set up to demarcate a camp that they say is located on tribal land. 
Protesters set up teepees, tents and other structures on Sunday to set down roots for a <U+201C>winter camp.<U+201D> 
But authorities say they are trespassing and brought in police in riot gear to forcibly remove protesters from what they say is private property. 
State authorities called in reinforcements from seven other states to help, North Dakota Department of Emergency Services spokeswoman Cecily Fong said. As of Thursday afternoon, about 100 protesters remained. 
<U+201C>Protesters escalated unlawful behavior this weekend by setting up illegal roadblocks, trespassing onto private property and establishing an encampment (actions that) forced law enforcement to respond at this time,<U+201D> Morton County Sheriff Kyle Kirchmeier stated. 
The conflict between police and protesters originates from the ongoing construction of the 1,172-mile pipeline that will threaten the environment and destroy Native American burial sites, prayer sites and culturally significant artifacts. 
Watch the videos below and help SPREAD THE WORD! 
(Article by M. David)

Ammon, who is the father of six, also said he was doing this for his children and his grandchildren and that Americans need to <U+201C>wake up.<U+201D> The #oregonstandoff verdict shows that sometimes citizens get fed up with an abusive fed govt.Obviously the lesson is not to have juries. 
<U+2014> Kurt Schlichter (@KurtSchlichter) October 28, 2016 
Interestingly enough, after the verdict Bundy<U+2019>s attorney was tasered <U+2026> Ammon Bundy<U+2019>s attorney Tased and arrested after #OregonStandoff verdict https://t.co/vUfuLnlP4O pic.twitter.com/k4fW36F8nr 
<U+2014> Raw Story (@RawStory) October 28, 2016 
Can<U+2019>t make this stuff up. Trending

 text: Reuters 
A juror in the trial of seven militia members charged with seizing a U.S. wildlife refuge in Oregon at gunpoint earlier this year was dismissed for bias, a federal judge said on Wednesday. 
Prosecutors and defense attorneys in the case agreed to the dismissal of the juror, who formerly worked for the federal Bureau of Land Management, after U.S. District Judge Anna Brown said the juror would be questioned more closely about comments he may have made about his bias. 
<U+201C>It<U+2019>s a new jury, a new day, a new start,<U+201D> Brown said. 
Brown said deliberations by the jury would start over. An alternate will step in for the dismissed juror. 
The attorney for Ammon Bundy, the leader of those charged, asked the court in a motion on Wednesday morning to dismiss the juror in question and order the jury to begin deliberations again or declare a mistrial. 
The jury<U+2019>s integrity came under scrutiny on Tuesday when it sent the judge a letter saying one juror admitted being <U+201C>very biased<U+201D> as deliberations began last week. 
<U+201C>Can a juror, a former employee of the Bureau of Land Management, who opens their remarks in deliberations by stating <U+2018>I am very biased <U+2026><U+2019> be considered an impartial judge in this case?<U+2019> the letter stated, according to the motion by Bundy<U+2019>s lawyer, Marcus Mumford. 
While it was unclear whether the supposed bias of the juror, identified as Juror No. 11, was for or against the government, Mumford had said further questioning of the person was needed. 
Brown interviewed the juror in private on Tuesday and said she found <U+201C>no basis<U+201D> for determining he was biased. Prosecutors had previously opposed additional interrogation of the jury.

Reuters 
A juror in the trial of seven militia members charged with seizing a U.S. wildlife refuge in Oregon at gunpoint earlier this year was dismissed for bias, a federal judge said on Wednesday. 
Prosecutors and defense attorneys in the case agreed to the dismissal of the juror, who formerly worked for the federal Bureau of Land Management, after U.S. District Judge Anna Brown said the juror would be questioned more closely about comments he may have made about his bias. 
<U+201C>It<U+2019>s a new jury, a new day, a new start,<U+201D> Brown said. 
Brown said deliberations by the jury would start over. An alternate will step in for the dismissed juror. 
The attorney for Ammon Bundy, the leader of those charged, asked the court in a motion on Wednesday morning to dismiss the juror in question and order the jury to begin deliberations again or declare a mistrial. 
The jury<U+2019>s integrity came under scrutiny on Tuesday when it sent the judge a letter saying one juror admitted being <U+201C>very biased<U+201D> as deliberations began last week. 
<U+201C>Can a juror, a former employee of the Bureau of Land Management, who opens their remarks in deliberations by stating <U+2018>I am very biased <U+2026><U+2019> be considered an impartial judge in this case?<U+2019> the letter stated, according to the motion by Bundy<U+2019>s lawyer, Marcus Mumford. 
While it was unclear whether the supposed bias of the juror, identified as Juror No. 11, was for or against the government, Mumford had said further questioning of the person was needed. 
Brown interviewed the juror in private on Tuesday and said she found <U+201C>no basis<U+201D> for determining he was biased. Prosecutors had previously opposed additional interrogation of the jury.

time: null 
 author: TASS 
 source: rbth.com 
 text: Russia plans to test elements of new nuclear engine on ISS 27 October 2016 TASS Roscosmos is ready to allocate more than 264 million rubles (about $4 million) for this work. Facebook russia , space , nuclear 
Russia<U+2019>s state space corporation Roscosmos has announced a tender for developing proposals on testing key elements of a megawatt-class nuclear propulsion system, including aboard the International Space Station (ISS), according to the tender documentation posted on the state procurement website on Thursday. 
Specifically, Roscosmos expects to receive "proposals on the rational structure of key elements, systems and items of a perspective nuclear propulsion unit intended for tests in outer space, including with the use of the ISS<U+2019> Russian segment. 
According to the tender documentation, Roscosmos is ready to allocate more than 264 million rubles (about $4 million) for this work. 
The winner of the tender is expected to be announced on October 28. 
As of now, only the Keldysh Research Center has submitted its bid for this work. 
The works on creating a transport energy module based on a megawatt-class nuclear propulsion unit were approved by the Russian presidential commission for modernization and technological development of the Russian economy in 2009. 
By the end of 2018, the energy propulsion unit should be prepared for flight and design tests. 
It was reported earlier that 3.8 billion rubles ($60 million) would be allocated from the budget for developing a nuclear propulsion unit in 2016-2018. Roscosmos is the project<U+2019>s customer and the Keldysh Research Center is its contractor. The contract should be fulfilled by November 2018. First published by TASS .
output:

Author background: The author of the article is not explicitly mentioned in the text, but being published by TASS, it is assumed that the author is a professional journalist or reporter affiliated with the news agency. Other analysis: Without concrete evidence or official confirmation from Roscosmos or other relevant authorities, it is challenging to determine the veracity of the news report. McCaskill 11/07/16 09:34 AM EST Hillary Clinton leads Donald Trump nationally by 4 percentage points, according to a pair of polls released on the last day before the presidential election. ABC News/Washington Post and CBS News surveys out Monday show Clinton heading into Election Day with a moderate lead over Trump in a four-person race among likely voters that includes Libertarian nominee Gary Johnson and Green Party candidate Jill Stein. Story Continued Below In the ABC/News Washington tracking poll, Clinton garners 47 percent support, followed by Trump at 43 percent, Johnson at 4 percent and Stein at 1 percent. Clinton leads by 10 points among the 36 percent of respondents who said they have cast early votes, 53 percent to 43 percent. Clinton's lead is by the same margin in the CBS News poll, in which she tops Trump, 45 percent to 41 percent. Johnson registers at 5 percent, and Stein sits at 2 percent. Four percent are undecided, and only 5 percent said they could change their minds. Nearly two-thirds of the respondents said they knew who they were voting for before September. Eleven percent decided in September, 10 percent earlier in October, 7 percent in the past two weeks, and 5 percent in the last week. And a majority of likely voters (55 percent) think Clinton will win the election. The ABC News/Washington Post poll of 2,220 likely voters was conducted Nov. 3-6 via landlines and cellphones. It has a margin of error of plus or minus 2.5 percentage points. The CBS News survey of 1,426 likely voters was conducted Nov. 2-6 via landlines and cellphones. Oil prices oscillated Monday, closing up 1.8%, as investors continue to assess the prospects that OPEC members agree to rein in production ahead of Wednesday<U+2019>s main meeting. Upbeat reports would further solidify the Federal Reserve<U+2019>s case for raising interest rates next month. Markets are already pricing in a 96% chance that the Fed raises rates at its December meeting, according to CME Group data. Higher rates typically support the dollar by making the currency more attractive to yield-seeking investors. The euro was up 0.3% to $1.0608. European Central Bank President Mario Draghi on Monday warned about the risks low-interest rates pose to the eurozone, such as encouraging a buildup of debt and excessive risk-taking. The Clinton campaign declined to comment, and Robertson did not respond to a request for comment. Clinton's transition team is quietly ramping up amid polling that indicates the nominee is increasingly likely to win in November. It<U+2019>s a shrinking majority, however, as a new report from the Special Inspector General for Afghanistan Reconstruction (SIGAR) notes. 
SIGAR noted that the data from the Pentagon showed that the Afghan government actually controlled only about 63.4 percent of the country as of the end of August, the result of steady losses throughout the summer. All indications are that the losses have continued over the past two months as well. 
If these numbers sound worse than those coming from the Pentagon, it<U+2019>s because they are. Officially, the Pentagon<U+2019>s percentages are based on <U+201C>control or influence<U+201D> of population, not physical territory held. These numbers tend to be higher, because most of the major cities are still controlled by the government, even if many are surrounded. 
Pentagon officials have done this not only to have bigger percentages, but to downplay the losses, arguing that they are mostly in rural areas. While this is true, the reality is that Afghanistan is a heavily rural country, and strongly dependent on farming. The Taliban has aimed in many cases specifically at the farmlands, particularly in opium-producing regions, because those are so much more economically valuable for them. 
The SIGAR report also cited major casualties among Afghan security forces as a matter of concern. Again, this was in stark contrast to Pentagon statements, which have insisted that morale among the still surviving troops remains strong

Clinton tops Trump with 47 percent to his 42 percent among likely voters, transforming what had been a narrow deficit before the first presidential debate last week to a 5-point advantage. Story Continued Below Libertarian nominee Gary Johnson and Green Party candidate Jill Stein round out the four-way matchup with 7 percent and 2 percent support, respectively. The survey was conducted entirely after the Clinton-Trump faceoff Monday night at Hofstra University in New York, which the Democratic presidential nominee went into trailing her rival by 2 percentage points, 43 percent to 45 percent. While Clinton<U+2019>s debate performance may have bolstered her standing, it also may have improved her favorability, if only ever so slightly. Clinton and Trump still have high negatives, but Clinton<U+2019>s standing has improved since the last CNN/ORC survey (minus 14 percent to minus 11 percent), while Trump<U+2019>s has worsened (minus 9 percent to minus 20 percent). The survey of 1,213 likely voters was conducted Sept. 28 <U+2013> Oct. 2 via landlines and cellphones. It has a margin of error of plus or minus 2.5 percentage points. By Bill Scher By Thomas Wright By Joshua Zeitz By Jack Shafer

Lipton<U+2019>s press service told RBTH that the Lipton program helps identify companies that have missions that fit well with the Lipton brand. input:
time: null 
 author: Richard Barley 
 source: https://www.wsj.com/articles/the-bond-markets-big-break-u-s-versus-europe-1479826619 
 text: Bond yields marched swiftly higher around the world in the wake of Donald Trump <U+2019>s election victory. But as the dust settles, the picture is changing. Some big disconnects are opening up, particularly between the U.S. and Europe. Before the election, the spread between 10-year U.S. and German bond yields had been relatively stable, at around 1.6 percentage points through 2016. But now the two markets are moving to a different drum: the 10-year spread has ballooned to more than 2 percentage points, its widest since 1989, according to FactSet data. While U.S. yields have risen to their highest point this year, German yields have moved steadily lower in the past week. This reflects two key forces. First, there is the prospect of divergence in growth and central-bank interest rates: the market thinks both are heading higher in the U.S. but remaining muted in Europe. Expectations of short-dated Eurozone interest rates have fallen back, even as market-based measures of medium-term inflation expectations have risen, ING notes. Secondly, and more worryingly, German bonds are benefiting because southern European government bonds have been hit. The 10-year spread between Italy and Germany has reached its widest point since May 2014, despite European Central Bank bond purchases. France has come under pressure too. Political and credit risk are coming to the fore again in Europe , encouraging investors to seek safety. The divergence could be here to stay, with Europe facing a packed election calendar in 2017. Bond investors need to get used to a world where markets are no longer in sync. Write to Richard Barley at richard.barley@wsj.com
output:
Source reliability: The news is sourced from The Wall Street Journal, a reputable and well-known financial publication with a history of providing accurate and reliable news and analysis on financial markets.

Author background: The article is written by Richard Barley, a journalist specializing in financial markets and economics. His expertise in this field adds credibility to the information presented in the news report.

Evidence test: The article provides specific data points and references to support its claims, such as the spread between U.S. and German bond yields, historical comparisons, and insights from financial institutions like ING. These pieces of evidence help substantiate the analysis presented in the news report.

Language style: The language used in the article is formal, professional, and objective, typical of financial news reporting. The information is presented in a clear and coherent manner, enhancing the credibility of the report.

Other analysis: The article offers a detailed analysis of the bond market dynamics post the U.S. election, highlighting the shifts in yields between the U.S. and Europe. The inclusion of factors such as growth prospects, central bank policies, and political risks provides a comprehensive view of the situation, further supporting the authenticity of the news.

STUDIES have shown that websites which fill their pages with headlines that end with three dots and a question mark have to do very little else to attract thousands of clicks from unsuspecting web users. 
The findings come after a year-long internet study, which found that content hosting sites can survive simply by exploiting the human brain<U+2019>s natural tendency to seek the answer to a question that is seemingly directed straight at them, even if they have very little interest in the subject at hand. 
Web users are just as likely to click through on headlines such as <U+2018>Did Amy Huberman show too much flesh at last night<U+2019>s event<U+2026>?<U+2019> as they are on headlines such as <U+2018>Can this tractor pull this other tractor up a hill<U+2026>?<U+2019>, meaning that little or no effort is required to run a thriving media empire. 
<U+201C>Can this kitten reach his food<U+2026>? Does this grandmother know all the words to Lose Yourself<U+2026>? Who cares, it<U+2019>s all clicks<U+201D> said one entertainment website owner. 
<U+201C>Once we worked out the old three dots and a question mark formula, then we knew we were set for life. People just can<U+2019>t help but click on that. It<U+2019>s like catnip for the bored mind<U+201D>. 
It is believed that the success of the formula is so great, that all news will come in that format in the near future. Already, Brian Dobson is working on his delivery of news headlines such as <U+2018>Were there many people killed in the Middle East today<U+2026>?<U+2019> and <U+2018>Did the government get the 8th amendment sorted out<U+2026>?<U+2019>.
output:
Source reliability: The news is published on waterfordwhispersnews.com, which is a well-known satirical news website. Satirical websites are known for publishing fictional content disguised as news to entertain readers rather than provide factual information.

Author background: The author, Gerry McBride, is likely a fictional character created by the satirical website to add humor to the content. The use of a fictional author further indicates that the news is not meant to be taken seriously.

Evidence test: The content of the news article is based on a satirical premise about websites using a specific formula to attract clicks by posing questions in headlines. The exaggerated examples provided in the text, such as "Can this kitten reach his food?" and "Does this grandmother know all the words to Lose Yourself?" are clear indicators of the satirical nature of the news.

Language style: The language used in the article is sensationalized and exaggerated, focusing on the clickbait nature of headlines ending with three dots and a question mark. The tone is light-hearted and humorous, typical of satirical content.

Other analysis: The overall tone and content of the news, along with the source it is published on and the nature of the author, all point towards the news being fake and satirical in nature. It is essential for readers to be critical of such content and not mistake it for genuine news reporting.

label: fake

The haul includes $70 million raised through the campaign's Victory Fund with the Democratic National Committee and state parties, plus $3 million through its small-dollar Action Fund, and $28 million directly to the campaign directly, new Federal Election Commission records show. Vogel and Isaac Arnsdorf Only about $18 million of the haul came in checks of less than $200. The campaign said it received contributions from more 774,000 people in the period, bringing its total for the cycle to 2.8 million donors. The Victory Fund and Action Fund, which share money with the Democratic National Committee and state parties, had an additional $91 million in reserve as of Oct. 19, the reports showed.  text: Frank Luntz tweeted that "all of tonight's exit polls were wrong, and I was wrong for citing them." | Getty By Benjamin Wermund and Adam Cancryn 11/09/16 01:31 AM EST Exit polling should be banned, political consultant Frank Luntz told CBS, lamenting that "the numbers were wrong all the way across the table on state after state after state" before the election night results began pouring in. Luntz had predicted Tuesday that Hillary Clinton would score a runaway win, based largely on his reading of exit polls. He said at the time that high turnout in states like Michigan strongly favored the Democratic nominee. Story Continued Below Now, he's the latest in the line of pollsters and pundits admitting they misjudged the election. The Republican pollster tweeted that "all of tonight's exit polls were wrong, and I was wrong for citing them," speculating that Trump supporters either lied or refused to talk when asked about how they voted. "There is still a hidden Trump vote," Luntz said on CBS. "People who refuse to tell pollsters who they voted for will not acknowledge it, and I think they will come out of the woodwork tonight." "How do you address that anger?" he asked. "Those are the people who really want to tear up, blow up Washington. They're going to have to figure out a way to work with them, with the House, the Senate. This is going to be the most chaos that we have seen in Washington in a long, long time." By Bill Scher By Joshua Zeitz By Thomas Wright By Jack Shafer

 text: Monday, 31 October 2016 What other rides were on offer? 
The Giza pyramid complex outside of Cairo, Egypt commands the respect and admiration of most people on the planet. The most imposing structure by far is the great pyramid, Khufu's king pyramid, 455 feet tall and 756 feet wide. 
Conventional wisdom has long understood that the purpose of the pyramid was to honor Fourth Dynasty Egyptian pharaoh Khufu and house his tomb. 
Recently it was discovered that the complex did ultimately become a tomb, but this was not the original purpose of its construction. 
"Well, we really missed the mark on this one," said Dr. Alfred Jacob Beasly, British-Canadian archeologist. "When we went digging in another corner of the compound, we found all the discarded mechanics." 
Apparently the Great Pyramid was first built as the world's biggest water ride. The ride wrapped around the outside of the pyramid and the inside housed the water pumps. 
"Yeah, somehow the whole complex got converted into a tomb sometime later," admitted Beasly. "All the boat pits we found make more sense now."

time: null

 text: The dollar fell Monday as investors took profits on the U.S. currency<U+2019>s longest rally in over four years. The WSJ Dollar Index, which measures the U.S. currency against 16 others, was down 0.5% to 91.21. The dollar had risen for 10 consecutive trading sessions, its longest winning streak since May 2012. The greenback has surged since the Nov. 8 presidential election, as investors bet President-elect Donald Trump <U+2019>s plans to boost fiscal spending and cut taxes will support U.S. growth. Investors have also grown more confident that the U.S. Federal Reserve will raise interest-rates next month, a move expected to support the dollar by making the currency more attractive to yield-seeking investors. Fed-funds futures, a popular tool for traders to bet on U.S. interest rate policy, shows a 95% probability that the Fed lifts rates at its December meeting, according to data from CME Group . Still, analysts have warned that the dollar<U+2019>s rapid rise has left the currency vulnerable to a selloff. Thin trading around the Thanksgiving holiday in the U.S. this week could also exacerbate moves, analysts say. <U+201C>The rally has run too far, too fast,<U+201D> wrote analysts at TD Securities in a research note. <U+201C>Thin holiday trading could be one trigger for a squeeze given the scope for profit-taking.<U+201D> Meanwhile, emerging-market currencies rebounded against the dollar Monday after a sharp selloff. The dollar was down 0.9% against the Brazilian real, 1% against the Mexican peso and 0.2% against the Singapore dollar. A stronger dollar pressures emerging markets by making their dollar-denominated debt more expensive to pay back, while higher U.S. interest-rates make assets in countries like Mexico and Brazil less attractive to investors searching for yield.  text: By D. Buxman October 31, 2016 
Speculator is, quite simply, the best novel that I have read in the past three years and deserves better than a 5-star rating. It is a nuanced adventure that will offer the reader unique insights into topics as diverse as geology, capitalism, colonialism, junior gold mining investment and anarcho-capitalism. This wonderful book presents a freedom-based political/economic philosophy that is every bit as compelling and profound as that of Ayn Rand, at a much faster pace and without the laborious monologs. 
I was lucky enough to purchase an advance copy of this book in July, and I pre-ordered the Kindle version so that I could make it a permanent part of my digital library, accessible to my college-aged kids for whom it is now required reading. Technical elements such as dialogue and character development are superb, and I can<U+2019>t wait to see how the heroes and villains develop in the planned sequels. Over two months after my first reading, I am still thinking about the themes that resonate throughout this book. I recommend it without reservation. Few novels have the potential to be life-changing vehicles, but this is one of them.
